Electron capture processes in a static electromagnetic field

description.en: The electron capture processes in collisions of (O5+ + C6+) and (C3+ + N7+) systems under a static electromagnetic field are studied by using a molecular-orbital based close-coupling method. The electric field effect in the electron capture cross section is always larger than the magnetic field effect at the same field strength in the atomic unit. (C) 2003 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Electron capture processes in a static electromagnetic field

description.en: The electron capture processes in collisions of (O5+ + C6+) and (C3+ + N7+) systems under a static electromagnetic field are studied by using a molecular-orbital based close-coupling method. The electric field effect in the electron capture cross section is always larger than the magnetic field effect at the same field strength in the atomic unit. (C) 2003 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Two-electron capture processes in collisions of Be4+ and Be3+ ions with He atoms

description.en: Double-electron capture processes are studied in collisions of Be3+ and Be4+ ions with He atoms below 10 keV amu(-1) by using a molecular-state expansion method. There is no study for the two electron processes between the Be3+ ions and the He atoms. On the other hand, for the (Be4+ + He) system a few calculations have been reported until now for the two-electron capture, in which there is a pretty large difference. (C) 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Interacion potential for Li<sup>+</sup> - He at small distance
Spin-exchange cross section for a He-3(+) ion incident on a Rb atom

description.en: Spin-exchange cross sections between a He-3(+) ion and a Rb atom were calculated in a He-3(+) impact-energy range from 0.01 to 10 keV/amu by the semiclassical close-coupling method based on the molecular-orbital expansion. The previous calculation in which only two states of the He-3(+) (1s S-2) + Rb(5s S-2) system were taken into account overestimated the experimental result at 6.33 keV/amu by orders of magnitudes, whereas the present calculation, which allowed the target excitation and electron transfer, showed a rough agreement with the experimental result. In view of the application, the spin-exchange cross sections larger than 10(-14) cm(2), predicted at He-3(+) impact energies lower than 0.3 keV/amu will hopefully provide a powerful tool for producing a highly polarized He-3 ion beam.

paper_title.en: Spin-exchange cross section for a He-3(+) ion incident on a Rb atom

description.en: Spin-exchange cross sections between a He-3(+) ion and a Rb atom were calculated in a He-3(+) impact-energy range from 0.01 to 10 keV/amu by the semiclassical close-coupling method based on the molecular-orbital expansion. The previous calculation in which only two states of the He-3(+) (1s S-2) + Rb(5s S-2) system were taken into account overestimated the experimental result at 6.33 keV/amu by orders of magnitudes, whereas the present calculation, which allowed the target excitation and electron transfer, showed a rough agreement with the experimental result. In view of the application, the spin-exchange cross sections larger than 10(-14) cm(2), predicted at He-3(+) impact energies lower than 0.3 keV/amu will hopefully provide a powerful tool for producing a highly polarized He-3 ion beam.

Charge transfer in collisions of lithium ions with beryllium through oxygen ions at energies below 32 keV/amu(jointly worked)
Dynamical study on resonance by using a wave packet propagation method: Electron capture in collision of N5+ ions with H atoms

description.en: To establish the dynamical aspects of shape resonance, we investigate the electron capture processes NS+ + H --> N4+(4s, 4p) + H+ by using a wave packet propagation method that can treat non-adiabatic collision processes. It is found that the incident wave packet is trapped into quasi-bound potentials when the collision energy coincides with that of the rovibrational state of the quasi-molecule. The wave packet component trapped in the N5+ + H effective potential transfers to electron capture channels rather than returns to the initial channel by tunneling again.
